Award.AwardTitle: An Experimental Study on the Role of Pore Fluid Pressure During Slow Slip in Subduction Zones
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Melodie French has been granted an NSF Earth Sciences postdoctoral fellowship to carry out a research and education plan at the University of Maryland, College Park. She will use experimental methods to characterize the effects of pore fluid pressure on slip processes in subduction zone rocks. Geophysical observations indicate that high fluid pressures occur in regions of subduction zones characterized by slow slip, which is behavior intermediate between standard seismicity and steady creep. Despite the fact that slow slip likely increases shear stress on the seismogenic plate boundary and may contribute to the nucleation of destructive earthquakes, little is known about the effects of very high fluid pressure on slip processes at the relevant pressure and temperature conditions. The results of this research program will constrain the processes that cause slow slip in subduction zones. Undergraduate students will be included in the execution of the research as part of their senior thesis requirements. In addition to working with students on the technical aspects of the research, Dr. French will mentor students in fulfilling requirements that develop their scientific communication skills.

Seismic hazards associated with slow slip include (1) triggered seismicity along the updip seismogenic portion of subduction zones and (2) downdip and landward propagation of a seismic slip event. The focus of this work is to determine the micro-mechanisms of slow slip, and to provide constitutive relations that can be used to model seismic hazards associated with slow slip events. To accomplish these goals, Dr. French will conduct a set of experimental studies to document faulting and slip under the temperature and stress conditions that slow slip occurs. The effects of both high and increasing pore fluid pressure on failure rates, stress drops, and strength will be determined in antigorite-rich serpentinite. A set of novel experimental stress paths will be employed to test published and new hypotheses on the stabilizing effects of pore fluid. In addition to the experimental work, detailed microstructural analyses will characterize and quantify the deformation mechanisms that cause slow slip behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Faults may slip rapidly, producing an earthquake, or slowly at the rates tectonic plates slide past one another. In some locations, faults slip at rates intermediate between these two end-members and experience episodes of `slow slip' punctuated by relative quiescence. This style of fault slip is not completely described by current physical models. Further, slow slip is thought to affect seismic hazards by redistributing stress along the fault and increasing stress in regions known to produce earthquakes. There are several observations to suggest that fluids exist at very high pressure in regions that experience slow slip.

In this project, we conduct experiments to investigate the role that high fluid pressures play in controlling how faults slip. The experiments are conducted by subjecting fault rocks to pressures, fluid pressures, and temperatures representative of faulting conditions and stressing them until fault slip. The results of the experiments are used to constrain the processes that cause slow slip, and also provide equations for rock behavior that can be used to model seismic hazards associated with slow slip.

The results show that high fluid pressures do in fact cause faulting to occur more slowly than in the absence of high fluid pressure. In a series of three studies, we develop modifications to existing physical models of fault slip that take into consideration the role of elevated fluid pressure.

This project funded the research project of a postdoctoral fellow and also provided research opportunities for four undergraduate students, two of whom conducted senior theses related to this project. Results from this research was presented at four conferences, and, in the end, is expected to yield three publications.
